awd_titl_txt: RUI:  Molecular Mechanisms of Short-Range Electron Transfer in Metalloproteins
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will focus on understanding the molecular level mechanism of short-range electron transfer in proteins. All living systems obtain energy through electrons occupying high energy states, either through respiratory chains (food) or from light (photosynthesis). Electron transfer is a vital function of the many proteins responsible for storage, transfer, and transformation of this energy. While there is some understanding of the factors controlling charge transfer over longer distances, little is known about biological electron transfer at distances shorter than 1 nm. Filling this gap will advance the knowledge of the fundamental steps in bioenergetics. By developing computational and experimental models to predict and explain the key parameters of these reactions, a cohesive understanding of short-range biological electron transfer will be obtained. In addition, the project will provide research training for undergraduates and will support innovations in the science curriculum.


The system that will be studied is PpcA, a 3 heme cytochrome from Geobacter sulfurreducens, genetically modified and covalently labeled with a number of photosensitizers will be used as a model system to study charge transfer reactions. The kinetics of the reactions will be studied with time-resolved fluorescence and absorbance spectroscopies at room and cryogenic temperatures. The structural integrity of protein-photosensitizer complexes will be monitored with SAXS and CD spectroscopy. Extensive all-atom molecular dynamics simulations will be performed to predict structures and to evaluate structural dynamics. These predictions will be tested experimentally with a number of structural techniques. The collected kinetic data will be analyzed in the context of molecular structures and will be used to test and revise currently available computational and theoretical approaches for the prediction of electron transfer rates and pathways. This project will also facilitate curricular updates in a number of upper level laboratory courses at James Madison University.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
All living systems obtain energy through electrons occupying high energy states, either through respiratory chains (food) or from light (photosynthesis). Electron transfer is a vital function of the many proteins responsible for storage, transfer, and transformation of this energy. While there is some understanding of the factors controlling charge transfer over longer distances, little is known about biological electron transfer at distances shorter than 1 nm. Filling this gap is important to advance our knowledge of the fundamental steps in bioenergetics. This project was focused on understanding the molecular level mechanism of short-range electron transfer in proteins. By developing computational and experimental models to predict and explain the key parameters of these reactions, a cohesive understanding of short-range biological electron transfer can be obtained.

As our model system we used PpcA, a 3 heme cytochrome from Geobacter sulfurreducens, genetically modified and covalently labeled with a number of light-absorbing compounds (photosensitizers) used to initiate charge transfer reactions with short laser pulses. Besides using techniques allowing to measure and characterize how fast reactions occur, a significant effort was dedicated for rigorous experimental and computational studies of proteins structure. Our experimental results led us to a conclusion that in addition to previously known requirement for short distance for ultrafast electron transfer, it was also essential to have all components of electron transfer chains to be tightly bound to protein frameworks.

In addition to advancing the fundamental understanding of electron transfer processes in proteins, our results open opportunities for the application of the discovered principles in quantum biology, quantum information science, biomimetic electronics, and bioremediation application for soil and water. This project also funded research training of about 15 undergraduate students at James Madison University. The vast majority of them after graduation chose employment in STEM fields or continued their education in graduate programs in Biophysics and Biochemistry.

 


Last Modified: 11/06/2022
Modified by: Oleksandr Kokhan
